results.title: Would you kiss a naked man? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: R. Alan Gough, Mary McLeod and Northern Century Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in sexuality”.
Demonstrates that sexuality and nudity are a natural part of an honest relationship between two people who care for one another by presenting a dramatized interlude between two teenagers in which they discuss the meaning of their relationship and engage in sexual play. From the series “Concepts in Sexuality”.

results.title: Gambling with our lives
results.brief_description: Modern technology provides us with an ever improving standard of living. However we are recognising the tradeoffs we must make between the benefits of progress against the potential hazards to our health. Research indicates that 85% of all cancer may be caused by environmental factors. This program looks into and discusses some of this research suggesting that we owe it to ourselves to learn more about the hazards of our modern world. Narrated by Norman Rose.

results.title: Five steps to conflict resolution (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bruce Johnson, Dave Bell and Dave Bell Associates
results.brief_description: Dr. William Glasser presents five steps to help teachers and administrators deal with personal, classroom, school-wide and community related conflict. When conflicts arise it is desirable to have an approach that will turn it in to a positive experience.

results.title: Little people
results.brief_description: A film which explores the political and social issues which surround dwarfism. The film attempts to depict the potential that exists for lack of understanding for those whose physical difference has far-reaching implications in a world constructed according to physical norms.

results.title: Four score years and then
results.brief_description: Looks at the rehabilitation geriatric ward at St. James Hospital, South West London, and some of its patients, most of them over 80. Peter Millard, Professor of geriatric medicine, believes the very old can be made well again if they are given a belief in themselves. The program follows the progress of a number of patients.

results.title: The Walrus and the carpenter
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Spaull, Thomas Gasek and MS&TG
results.brief_description: An animated adaptation of Lewis Carroll’s whimsical poem in which the walrus and the carpenter entice a family of oysters to join them in their journey along the beach. Uses puppet animation. Narrated by Guy Spaull.

results.title: Animals: ways they eat
results.creator_credit: William A. Anderson and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Shows how the body parts of various animals are related to their eating habits. Includes such examples as the cirri or barnacles, the mouth parts and legs of crayfish, the teeth of lions and cows, the tongues of butterflies, the noses of hogs, the beaks of birds, and the paws of squirrels.

results.title: Ash Wednesday
results.brief_description: Documents the restoration of essential electricity supply to fire damaged areas of Victoria after the bushfires of Ash Wednesday, 1983. Shows the work done by the SEC crews and the conditions with which they had to cope.

results.title: Women climbing mountains
results.creator_credit: Lois Ellis and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A tribute to sculptor Henry Moore and contemporary woman’s search for new horizons. Features dance work on film choreographed by Margaret Barr with dancers Christina Cullen, Lin Kan and Jim MacLaine. No commentary.

results.title: Fall line
results.creator_credit: Bob Carmichael, Greg Lowe and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: An exciting film of the high risk sport of extreme skiing. On a peak in Wyoming’s Grand Tetons a lone skier attempts the first climb and then the fall line - a breathtaking descent of the almost vertical slope. Awarded first prize, Sports, San Francisco International Film Festival. The skier is Steve Shea and the film has been narrated by Ron Hayes.
